Thanks for the A2A! Usually, manufacturers tend to support major new generations of technology, especially in the case of networking, when they're established as standards. Some manufacturers, like Apple, tend to wait a couple years after the initial rollout to collect critical data such as feasibility, coverage and several other factors including problems that may arise during the initial adoption of such technology. In fact, Apple was the last major manufacturer to embrace 4G LTE with the iPhone 5 in 2012. Having said that, 5G is largely under research and development, and has not been established as a standard. There's still plenty of work left to achieve a standard that is not only as reliable as LTE but also improves upon its many facets. To answer your question, no, the iPhone 8 will not support 5G networks. In fact, it doesn't even support the best version of LTE(Gigabit LTE)! And when 5g does eventually roll out, you can bet good money Apple won't be amongst the first to adopt it
